title-group.article-title: Developing a New Stratified-Charge Combustion System with Fuel Injection for Reducing Exhaust Emissions in Small Farm and Industrial Engines

permissions.copyright-statement: Â© Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc., 1973

abstract.p: This paper describes a new stratified-charge combustion system called the Mitsubishi Combustion Process (MCP), accomplished by controlling the air swirl and improving the injection nozzle in regulating fuel injection, which reduces poisons from exhaust emissions of small engines. Experiments proved that the MCP engine reduces the emission level; for example, with gasoline the concentrations of HC, CO, and NO are 80 ppm, 0.20%, and 600 ppm, respectively, at the rated horsepower. The engine shows excellent performance in multifuel and starting characteristics. The improvement of spray formation that has an important effect on exhaust emissions and other engine performance is also described.

ref.mixed-citation: Keith H. Rhodes, "Project Stratofire." Paper 660094 presented at SAE Automotive Engineering Congress, Detroit, January 1966.
I. N. Bishop and Alader Simko, "A New Concept of Stratified Charge Combustion-The Ford Combustion Process (FCP)." SAE Transactions, Vol. 77 (1968), paper 680041.
A. W. Kaupert, G. E. Cheklick, and F. Lux, "Modified I-C Engine Reaches Proposed 1980 Emission Goals." SAE Journal, Vol. 79 (February 1971).
A. W. Hussmann, F. Kahoun, and R. A. Taylor, "Charge Stratification by Fuel Injection into Swirling Air." SAE Transactions, Vol. 71 (1963), pp. 421444.

Shunichi Ohigashi, Yoshisuka Hamamoto, and Seiichi Tanabe, "A New Digital Method for Measuring Gas Flow Velocity by Electric Discharge." Paper 690180 presented at SAE Automotive Engineering Congress, Detroit, January 1969.
